dataset.description:
This table shows historic aggregate use of force incidents and related complaints for the South Bend Police Department from 2014 through 2017. Beginning in 2017, use of force incidents and complaints were tracked at an incident level basis. You can go to the mapped use of force incident data here and the complaints data here.

To see incident level data visualized, please visit the SBPD Transparency Hub.

Calls for service, number of cases, and number of arrests are also provided for each year in order to provide context.
dataset.title: Use of Force - Annual Aggregates (Historic)

dataset.description:
This dataset provides information about complaints filed by staff of the South Bend Police Department against other staff. It includes the month and year of the complaint, the type, and the disposition or outcome. This dataset is cumulative, beginning 2018 and updated quarterly.

Things to note about this dataset:
  • Regardless of whether a complaint is filed, all uses of force go through the investigation process.
  • The MNBC column indicates whether or not an additional misconduct, that was not related to what the original investigation was for, is discovered by SBPD staff. (Ex, a driving infraction is noted by SBPD staff while reviewing an Administrative Investigation about professionalism).
  • Excessive Force and Use of Force are two different complaint types. Excessive Force questions if the amount of force was necessary while Use of Force questions whether the use of any force was necessary.
  • Open investigations are not part of this dataset, as they have not concluded yet.

For an expanded explanation on the process and definitions of dispositions, please refer to the Community Complaints Guide.

To see this data visualized, you can go to the SBPD Transparency Hub.
dataset.title: Administrative Investigations for SBPD

dataset.description:
Reflects applications created on or after April 12, 2017 that have been a part of completed recruitment cycles. Please note that each record/row is an application, not an applicant (i.e., an applicant may apply several times)

The "Last Hiring Stage" is reflective of the last stage that applicant completed in their application. For example, if the Last Hiring Stage completed is Passed Interview, they would count in every preceding stage. They would have received a "Background Fail" as their applicant status.

For context and additional information about this dataset, you can visit our Police Recruitment Data Guide.

This data will be updated within a month after the completion of recruitment cycles.
dataset.title: SBPD Recruitment Data

dataset.description:
This table is the demographic breakdown by Gender for Police recruitment. This summary will be updated within a month after the completion of recruitment cycles.

For context and additional information about this dataset, you can visit our Police Recruitment Data Guide.

Reflects applications created on or after April 12, 2017 that have been part of completed recruitment cycles.
dataset.title: SBPD Recruiting - Gender

dataset.description:

Reflects applications created on or after April 12, 2017 that have been part of completed recruitment cycles.
dataset.title: SBPD Recruiting - Ethnicity

dataset.description:
This dataset provides information about complaints filed by members of the public against South Bend Police Department. It includes the month and year of the complaint, the type, and the disposition or outcome. This dataset is cumulative, beginning 2016 and updated quarterly.

Things to note about this dataset:
  • Regardless of whether a complaint is filed, all uses of force go through the investigation process.
  • The Admin Investigations column indicates whether or not an additional misconduct, that was not related to what the original complaint was for, is discovered by SBPD staff while investigating the community complaint. (Ex, a driving infraction is noted by SBPD staff while reviewing a community complaint about professionalism).
  • Excessive Force and Use of Force are two different complaint types. Excessive Force questions if the amount of force was necessary while Use of Force questions whether the use of any force was necessary.
  • Open investigations are not part of this dataset, as they have not concluded yet.

For an expanded explanation on the process and definitions of dispositions, please refer to the Community Complaints Guide.

To see this data visualized, you can go to the SBPD Transparency Hub.
dataset.title: Community Complaints Reported to SBPD

dataset.description:
This is a map of all properties that are scheduled for inspection or are registered under South Bend's Rental Safety Verification Program (RSVP) and their corresponding status beginning March 2019.


It includes the following data:

  • Property identification details (parcel IDs and addresses)
  • Property RSVP status (please see terminology definitions below)
  • Expiration date of RSVP certification or exemption
  • Name of property owner and owner's business name (if applicable)
  • Location (coordinates may be missing for parcels that have been consolidated)
Terminology for property status:
  • Certified - property has met minimum standards
  • Condemned - property has extensive, major violations and the property is unsafe for occupancy
  • Conditional Certification - property requires non-critical repairs that can't be completed within 60 days (typically weather dependent, exterior repairs)
  • Does not Qualify for RSVP - property is owner-occupied and/or non-residential
  • Exempt - property does not require an RSVP inspection (most often due to having received an inspection by another agency in the last 12 months)
  • Illegal for Non-Owner Occupancy - inspections initiated or completed but property has not achieved certification
  • Inspection Process - property has an RSVP inspection scheduled
  • Under Review - we have initiated contact with the owner to schedule an inspection ~ or ~ someone has contacted Code Enforcement to schedule an inspection - but no inspection has been scheduled yet
This information is current as of March 2, 2020.

Updated weekly.
dataset.title: RSVP Properties

dataset.description:
This is a map of properties with Active Demolition Orders as of March 2, 2020.


Lists are limited to properties with active cases relating to Indiana's Unsafe Building Law managed by City of South Bend's Department of Code Enforcement. 


It includes the following data:

  • Property identification details (parcel IDs and addresses)
  • Indication of whether the property is vacant or abandoned
  • Structures ordered to be demolished
  • Location (coordinates may be missing for parcels that have been consolidated)
Updated weekly.
dataset.title: Active Demolition Orders

dataset.description:
This is a map of all properties that are or were Vacant and Abandoned and received a repair or demolition order on one or more structures on the property beginning April 2013.  

It includes the following data:

  • Status of the most recent case for the property and structure (active or closed)
  • Property identification details (parcel IDs and addresses)
  • Current order or upcoming hearing type for the property
  • Previous or upcoming hearing date
  • Details on the last compliance (for those properties that are closed or have been closed, then reopened)
  • Location (coordinates may be missing for parcels that have been consolidated)

The information is current as of March 2, 2020.

Updated weekly.
dataset.title: All Vacant and Abandoned Properties

dataset.description:
This is a data set of the City of South Bend's amended budget from 2019 broken down by revenue and expense accounts.

It includes the following data:
  • Fund: Fund means "cash" or a group of accounts set aside for the purpose of accounting for moneys or other resources of general functions or specific activities such as utilities, construction projects or other activities of a city or town in accordance with a system of accounts prescribed by the State Board of Accounts or as required by statute.
  • Department: The organizational unit typically classified by the functions or services performed by the unit.
  • Division: The organizational unit of a department. Some departments have only one division.
  • Subdivision: A further breakdown of the divisions within a department. Some departments have only one subdivision.
  • Main Account: The type of general ledger account for transaction and reporting purposes.
  • Account Type: A unique place in the general ledger that is used for recording a dollar balance along with a history of changes to that balance.
  • GL Account: General ledger account number.
This information is current as of December 31, 2019.
dataset.title: 2019 Amended Budget

  • Department: The organizational unit typically classified by the functions or services performed by the unit.
  • Division: The organizational unit of a department. Some departments have only one division.
  • Subdivision: A further breakdown of the divisions within a department. Some departments have only one subdivision.
  • Main Account: The type of general ledger account for transaction and reporting purposes.

dataset.description: Partial listing of social services available in St. Joseph County. Includes organization type, location, contact information, and hours of operation, if known. This is not a comprehensive list. For additional listings, visit the United Way website at http://www.myuw211.org/
dataset.title: Social Services St Joseph County

dataset.description:
Through the South Bend Certified Realtors Program, the City offers a successful program aimed at helping real-estate agents provide more in-depth information to potential buyers. The South Bend Certified Realtors Program serves to educate Realtors about South Bend's neighborhoods, economy, schools, culture and history. This up-to-date information allows them to do a better job of selling homes in our neighborhoods and assisting their buyers in making better decisions when purchasing their new homes.

South Bend Certified Realtors Program is an initiative of the City made up of a committee which includes local Realtors, representatives from the colleges and universities, Indiana Landmarks, Center for History, the media and the City.

This initiative promotes the neighborhoods of South Bend to residents, newcomers, the business community, universities, Realtors and builders as it:

1.  Better informs these and other groups about the South Bend's assets.

2. Provides these groups with information about housing options in South Bend's lovely neighborhoods.

3. Offers a list of South Bend Certified Realtors to assist new and existing employees with their housing needs.

4. Presents a series of classes to various groups and the general public to educate and inform them about the City's neighborhoods.

5. Sponsors events and works in collaboration with other organizations to promote housing within certain target areas of the City.

For more information about the South Bend Certified Realtors Program, to find a South Bend-certified Realtor, or to become certified, contact Sue Solmos, Residential Marketing Specialist in the Department of Neighborhood & Community Engagement, 574.235.5879, or ssolmos@southbendin.gov
dataset.title: South Bend Certified Realtors

dataset.description:
This document is a Working Agreement between the City of South Bend and the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 36.

The purpose of this Working Agreement is to:
  • Achieve and maintain harmonious relations between the City and the Lodge which are in the best interests of the Community.
  • Improve public safety in the areas of public police protection.
  • Provide for equitable and peaceful adjustment of differences which may arise.
  • Further a mutual and voluntary effort to promote and maintain sound labor relations.
  • Establish other conditions of employment.
This Agreement is effective from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2020.
dataset.title: Fraternal Order of Police Working Agreement

dataset.description:
This document is a Collective Bargaining Agreement between the Board of Public Safety, acting for and on behalf of the City of South Bend and the South Bend Firefighter's Association, Local No. 362 of the International Association of Firefighters, AFL-CIO.

The purpose of this Agreement is to:
  • Achieve and maintain harmonious relations between the City and the Union in the best interest of the community.
  • Provide for equitable and peaceful adjustment of differences which may arise.
  • Improve public safety in the areas of public firefighting services, emergency medical service, water and aerial rescue services, hazardous material emergency response services, swift water rescue, technical rescue, fire protection services in the area of Code Enforcement and public education, and fire and arson investigation services.
  • Establish hours and other conditions of employment.
This Agreement is effective from January 1, 2018 to December 31, 2021.
dataset.title: Firefighter's Local 362 Collective Bargaining Agreement

dataset.description: This dataset provides incident-level information on use of force incidents involving South Bend Police Officers. Incident-level data is released beginning in 2017 and updated after the end of each quarter. The location of the incident is rounded to the 100-block in order to protect the privacy and anonymity of residents involved.
dataset.title: Police Use of Force Incidents

dataset.title: Police Officer Commendations

dataset.description: This dataset includes fatal and non fatal, criminally assaulted shootings in South Bend from 2015 - 2018. It is updated annually. Note that location is provided at the 100 block level rather than the exact location of the incident. If the location of the incident is unknown, the incident will not appear on the map, but is included in the table. The time listed in the date/time field is a default time provided by the application and does not reflect the actual time of the incident.
dataset.title: Criminally Assaulted Shootings
